Elliott,

Namban <=> Nanban

~if your question about Namban related to Soten stems
from Aoi Arts' posting last night of a "Soten" tsuba
and them stating it is Namban, please know that it is
just a mistake by the Aoi Arts people.


Curran



--- Elliott <elliott@...> wrote:

> Thank you Dr. John, 
> I now need to add another name to my confusion or
> curiosity.... 
> Nanban tsuba.
> We have no comparison between Soten and Namban, is
> Nanban tsuba 
> related in some way to either Namban or Soten? It
> seems somewhere I 
> read about a Nanban tsuba signed Mogarashi Soten.
> Are these schools 
> related? I can see some likenesses between Nanban
> and Soten.
> As always, thank you and the group for my continuing
> education.
> Elliott
>  
> 
> 
> --- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "Dr John P
> Lissenden" 
> <docliss@...> wrote:
> >
> > Dear Elliot
> > 
> > I know of no relationship whatsoever between the
> Namban and the 
> Soten 
> > groups of tsuba.  The only feature that may be
> considered common to 
> > them both is some evidence of a Chinese influence.
>  However, while 
> > with Namban tsuba this resulted in a completely
> novel metalworking 
> > technique, Soten tsuba use conventional, Japanese
> techniques to 
> > illustrate historical sujects which may be of
> Chinese derivation.  
> > But there a lots of differences:-
> > 
> > Soten tsuba came initially from a recognised
> 'school' of makers, 
> > although they were later mass produced outside
> this.  There was 
> never 
> > a recognised Namban 'school', the namban influence
> being ubiquitous.
> > 
> > Namban tsuba had their origin in China, were
> imported into Japan at 
> > the end of the C16, and reached the peak of their
> popularity in the 
> > late C18.  Soten tsuba date from the early C18 and
> continued to be 
> > made, as poor quality shiiremono, into the late
> Edo period.  
> > (Although I have no evidence for this, I suspect
> that many of the 
> > latter may also have been produced using the 'lost
> wax' method of 
> > casting.)
> > 
> > True examples of the Namban group are
> characterised by extensive 
> > openwork and undercutting, whereas with Soten
> tsuba, while they may 
> > demonstrate some degree of openwork, this is not a
> constant feature 
> > and never includes undercutting.
> > 
> > Namban tsuba commonly have profuse gold
> decoration, either as 
> nunome-
> > zogan or fire gilding.  Soten tsuba are
> characterised by selective 
> > and delicate inlays of gold, silver, copper and
> shakudo.
> > 
> > Soten tsuba do not demonstrate the decorartive
> mimi, seppa-dai and 
> > ryo-hitsu which characterise Namban tsuba. 
> Signatures, although 
> > admittedly usually gimei, feature frequently on
> Soten tsuba and 
> > almost never in the Namban group.
> > 
> > The design on Soten tsuba is themed, being is
> representative of 
> > specific characters or incidents, while that on
> Namban tsuba is 
> > purely decorative. 
> > 
> > No, I personally know of no relationship between
> the two groups.
> > 
> > Regards, John L.
> > 
> > 
> > --- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "Elliott"
> <elliott@> wrote:
> > >
> > > First, I appreciate all the comments that were
> made in reference 
> to 
> > my 
> > > question about 'cast' tsuba. And all the
> discussion about Namban 
> > leads 
> > > me to my next question for the group......
> > > 
> > > What is the relationship between Nanban Tsuba
> and Soten Tsuba? 
> > > 
> > > Thanks,
> > > 
> > > Elliott
> > >
> >
> 
> 
>
